234A5C1496944760B20505D077E57325.description: Communicate research findings related to crop production-related occupations through a display, brochure, video, presentation software, website or an oral presentation.

72041D1A52A146AABFB1DD63EACCD99A.description: Research experience and qualifications for newcomers to enter the crop production industry.

7643D8519CF44F208BE6768883E56132.description: Explore opportunities for underrepresented populations in the crop production industry.

82F9AAACDCED414488D4028AAF3755C9.description: Reflect upon personal suitability for a specific crop production-related occupation considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties and skills required for this occupation; the work environment, including typical hours, shifts worked and locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to the rest of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; apprenticeship and/or certification requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and, future trends impacting the agriculture sector.

548EBFB8954B44C089E8FE79D3CB6499.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common to people involved in crop productionrelated jobs

6A951D3D05614C7A91DD690708A2FF97.description: Investigate occupations related to crop production (e.g., agricultural economist, agrologist and soil and plant scientist).

2F995C6985F847AAA4EC2F406987BE87.description: Explore the advances in technology used to adapt unsuitable areas for crop production (e.g., irrigation and drain tile).

F0D5A2D0A6E44D699ABE48681E66B4C6.description: Research the effects of advances in technology in one or more of the following areas: weather, soil and crop monitoring; • processing data; identification of insects, diseases and weeds; distribution and marketing of crops; storage; safer growing conditions; safer foods; communication; reduced environmental and ecological impact (air and water quality); higher productivity (workers and crop yield); decreased use of water, fertilizer and pesticides; increased worker safety; GMO crops; and, independence of producers (e.g., performing their own soil tests).

0CC2DEAB52284DBC8D988B37AB659188.description: Investigate the use of technology in crop production.

BD44034CB3094AF0AF023258C52F9DCD.description: Explain the function of equipment (e.g., water heating system, extractor and air-circulation fans, cooling system, fog system and climate control) used in greenhouse facilities to ensure optimal growing conditions.

092BA9C0D4294CC8AD10292F3A394BE8.description: Identify the equipment (e.g., spray tank, boom, check valves, nozzles) attached to an airplane or helicopter to facilitate aerial application of pesticides (i.e., fungicide, herbicide and insecticide).

61CCED0853194675A68C00CA93263B4D.description: Explain the role of equipment (e.g., seeder, mower, irrigation, cutter, roller and forklift) used in sod production.

3AD0F94B7DCC41178DE72B5FFF9FA0E2.description: Describe how machinery can be calibrated for different crops (e.g., transplanter for onions and cabbages, sprayers for different pesticides, irrigation systems for drip and spray and harvesters for carrots and beets).

589099EA5DE941399EAA2A94F1E1398A.description: Investigate the equipment used in vegetable and fruit farming and explain the importance of specialized spreaders and harvesters (e.g., compact spreader, fruit harvester and pruning tower) in the industry.

E93C6D9D82F447028E2F72F67942B35D.description: Discuss ways to mitigate the safety risks of climbing on top of storage structures (e.g., grain bins).

2F5CD78702F440698A6843CB810B1364.description: Explain the design and operation of different types of irrigation equipment (e.g., pumps, piping, pivot, wheel-move and hand-move).

AEA515F8FF9946159FC8E4D758B36C61.description: Identify issues associated with water management related to agriculture production in Saskatchewan, including: ripple effect-how one action can impact another’s land; impact of individual local decisions on watersheds; surface runoff of pesticides, fertilizer and manure; leaching of nitrogen into groundwater; and, intended and unintended consequences of human altered water drainage patterns.

3C7244E399964ECF9F25245172B56941.description: Research the characteristics (e.g., size, slope, shape, drainage, land use and cover, geology and soils) of the local watershed.

3E1E1853620647BEA080173890F8DC70.description: Investigate the importance of water stewardship in sustainable agriculture production

1869602471C54CB684903D83B8A0B2A5.description: Explore programs and services that do not align with First Nations policy and cannot be used by First Nations peoples.

BE789A7A496243F6870DAF31AC55B5FF.description: Analyze livestock and crop production information from various sources (e.g., blogs/vlogs, Saskatchewan Soil Information System [SKSIS] and Community Collaborative Rain, Hail and Snow Network [CoCoRHS]).

A8E31C37171C4BA5AB596FD6B11AE845.description: Explain the need for reliable information in all production sectors.

9F300B5F0F8E42D88E364FA4084CCB36.description: Discuss valuable skills (e.g., positive self-perception, effective communication, stress management and a positive social network) for maintaining positive psychological health.

10FD3C3132604C7DAB26E163BC0CB22F.description: Examine the effects that experiences (e.g., residential schools and intergenerational trauma and farm accident) can have on individuals and communities.

ABD869BC76A446D6896F38519D382DCC.description: Examine the signs and symptoms of stress: emotional (e.g., anxiety, burnout, irritability, angry outbursts); mental (e.g., constant worry, poor concentration, conflict avoidance); spiritual (e.g., feeling of depression or abandonment, doubts in spiritual or religious beliefs); and, physical (e.g., dizziness, headache, muscle aches, nausea, sleep disturbance, fatigue, higher rates of accidents and injuries).

86E0E5E9A8ED42F290DD859E64E8C9EA.description: Investigate the impact of social media, culture, lack of community resources and an unsupportive social network on mental health.

751DB1540D7948F18126C138F8A6408F.description: Analyze the factors (e.g., loss of a loved one, divorce, poor farm year caused by drought and imbalances in chemical, neurological, hormonal and biological systems) that may contribute to mental illness.

0C393ED491694F998C2864EF1EB210E2.description: Explore the environmental impacts of unsafe chemical waste disposal, and how that impacts Indigenous communities (e.g., water, animals and traditional medicinal plants).

6D82C8C00329447A8F7AE79789F0C702.description: Investigate the responsibilities and correct environmental handling, cleanup and waste disposal of cleaners, containers, coolants, filters, fuel and lubricants (e.g., grease and oil) including organizations that specialize in their cleanup

FEE1245AD26C44858DA0F97CDA26C4AC.description: Describe the four parts of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) (i.e., labels with warning symbols, hazard identification and product classification, Safety Data Sheets (SDS), worker education and worksite specific training).

88154412F4CD4E559B7411D409D7A405.description: Identify important information categories from product labels, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) and manufacturer’s chemical information packages such as compatibility, storage requirements, application method, preharvest intervals and withdrawal periods.

6C40242622C04FF9BD99308DCB37C98E.description: Describe basic response plans for common types of emergencies in agriculture operations (e.g., fire, medical aid, entrapment, violent threat, severe storms).

8B43B7D191C64EA29184DB9EAB329A49.description: Research the benefits of completing certifications and programs offered by Work Safe Sask (Mental Health and Wellness, Occupational Health and Safety and Young Career Worker Readiness), Sask Safety Council (Online Agriculture Training System – OATS and Career Safety Education), Motor Safety Association (Introduction to Workplace Safety), Agricultural Health and Safety Network (Respiratory Health in Ag), Sask Prevention (Farm Safety) and the Ministry of Labour Relations and Workplace Safety (Farm Safety).

7FD791A9C483498B8432A8CEBACD6EB3.description: Describe the worker’s three rights: the right to know, the right to participate and the right to refuse unsafe work.

B2546098091141A69BB392686F1BFE97.description: Identify when an Occupational Health and Safety (OH&S) program is required by law for an agriculture production operation

4620925C1778413EB7AE6BF35880F2BB.description: Identify sections of the Saskatchewan Employment Act that apply to owners, employers, contractors, supervisors, suppliers, self-employed persons and workers as it relates to agriculture production operations.

5E039ED1BAC243C68CD4F724FEA0AE9F.description: Identify the positive and negative effects to using each category (e.g., respiratory, hearing, vision, skin and body) of industry standard personal protective equipment.

6E22970993C54751AB8899936E85C1E4.description: Explore ways to mitigate risk of damage to equipment (e.g., maintenance schedule, pre-use inspections, scheduled inspections, understanding manufacturer’s recommendations and reporting damage).

7839E77B34AD40E4A712EF3CD4980642.description: Analyze and describe the effect of lost production time due to equipment damage or personal injury during critical times of the year (e.g., seeding, harvest, calving).

34C666BA5CE5445AA3022F43D9225A2B.description: Investigate the impact of major events offered in Saskatchewan that promote agriculture.

FF879E1A7621478895CF7CE5777B31FC.description: Identify current events, trends and issues (e.g., population growth and climate change) affecting the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan

FA973B89D99C4722AC8E1C74CB03A60D.description: Explore how agriculture, carbon sequestration, and sustainable agriculture practices can be part of nature-based climate solutions.

5AAF5C15665B49D2B492E2B3D324693F.description: Explore Saskatchewan’s agricultural value regarding growing, processing and exporting food for provincial, national and global markets.

AE2B18C0A7934B19BFE5EE9F32E29A45.description: Describe related services that support agriculture production (e.g., research, storage and transportation).

ED68ED7D97134F96856DE47C79069258.description: Apply terms commonly associated with the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan

A5274FD2977F4DC082835DD136BA0FEF.description: Research terms commonly associated with the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan, including: biosecurity; commodities; consumers; diversified agriculture; livestock; markets; mixed farming; plant protein; primary production; producers; product; production agriculture; secondary industry; and, value-added agriculture.

90467D785B654A4AB454E5F2F6DB5A01.description: Examine agriculture’s connections to Saskatchewan’s economy

F365B49C41D44DE18355EA9525A3FCD8.description: Investigate the impact and significance of agriculture in Saskatchewan.
